Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2013 11:11AM MelissaDallas wrote: Sara, you are incorrect.  A BIRADS 4 MRI indicates a suspicious area that needs a biopsy, (nothing to do with the skill of the person doing the test)  usually a stereotactic biopsy.   BIRADS 4 are most often masses or clusters of calcifications. Fine needle aspirations are generally done on cysts.  Cysts have a characteristic appearance on ultrasounds and MRIs and do not generally generate a BIRADS four category.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2013 06:17PM MelissaDallas wrote: Concerned, why do you assume her area of LCIS didn't show up on MRI? MRI's tend to show so much stuff they cause false POSITIVES. If you are thinking that the LCIS was a separate mass, I don't believe that was necessarily true. They do the MRI to check that there are not other things not seen on mammo. Just because the atypical cells got upgraded doesn't mean they were separate. For example, my stereotactic biopsy was ALH, suspicious for LCIS. My MRI did not show any extra area of concern. When my ALH mass was removed by excisional biopsy and they looked at a bigger chunk than was removed by core it was, in fact upgraded to LCIS.

My breast doctor told me it's too hard to see anything while breastfeeding and can't while pregnant, so I put it off. I also moved from Az to Ca and didn't have a well established Dr, so no one to run to as I would in AZ where I had a breast Dr and awesome OBGYN. My friend referred me to this new OB for mid period bleeding. That was in May. I mentioned it to my Ob/gyn, who I'm seeing for the mentioned other female issues(ovarian cysts that we are "monitoring" for change) , but couldn't find the lump on my breast that day. He wanted me back in 2 weeks for my ovarian u/s first and said we could do a breast U/s too, but never wrote it up. Just my abdominal u/s I really wrote it off. The other day i was at my Ob following up on my other issues and just remembered at the end of my appt to ask about my lump. Imentioned the lump which I recently "refound," which, now, I could feel. I don't know that it's bigger, just that It's maybe more prominent. It's hard, round edges and moves a bit, not a ton but a bit... and so when he felt it, he grew very concerned.... put my other issues (which I was very worried about) on the back burner and very stern, asked me how long it's been there. I wasn't sure. I thought it had gone away and being more concerned with my other issues, just mentioned a couple of weeks maybe. (But now thinking back, as I mentioned, it's really been months... This time he noted the mass and drew the spot, cited as a 1cm mass. It's not 1 cm though... it's pea sized, small pea at that. Maybe a few montrhs ago, maybe longer... maybe much longer. Posts.Content: Oct 25, 2013 06:27AM MelissaDallas wrote: Here is a study that shows they are 96.8% effective. A tenpercent false negative sounded a little high to me.  AJR Am J Roentgenol. 2010 Jun;194(6):1674-9. doi: 10.2214/AJR.09.3568. Shimauchi A, Jansen SA, Abe H, Jaskowiak N, Schmidt RA, Newstead GM. Department of Radiology, The University of Chicago, Chicago, IL 60637, USA. ashimauc@radiology.bsd.uchicago.edu The objective of our study was to determine the sensitivity of cancer detection at breast MRI using current imaging techniques and to evaluate the characteristics of lesions with false-negative examinations. Two hundred seventeen patients with 222 newly diagnosed breast cancers or highly suspicious breast lesions that were subsequently shown to be malignant underwent breast MRI examinations for staging. Two breast imaging radiologists performed a consensus review of the breast MRI examinations. The absence of perceptible contrast enhancement at the expected site was considered to be a false-negative MRI. Histology of all lesions was reviewed by an experienced breast pathologist. Enhancement was observed in 213 (95.9%) of the 222 cancer lesions. Of the nine lesions without visible enhancement, two lesions were excluded because the entire tumor had been excised at percutaneous biopsy performed before the MRI examination and no residual tumor was noted on the final histology. The overall sensitivity of MRI for the known cancers was 96.8% (213/220); for invasive cancer, 98.3% (176/179); and for ductal carcinoma in situ, 90.2% (37/41). In a population of 220 sequentially diagnosed breast cancer lesions, we found seven (3.2%) MRI-occult cancers, fewer than seen in other published studies. Small tumor size and diffuse parenchymal enhancement were the principal reasons for these false-negative results. Although the overall sensitivity of cancer detection was high (96.8%), it should be emphasized that a negative MRI should not influence the management of a lesion that appears to be of concern on physical examination or on other imaging techniques.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2014 08:54AM MelissaDallas wrote: From the Mayo Clinic website: Mammary duct ectasia (ek-TAY-zhuh) occurs when a milk duct beneath your nipple becomes wider (dilated), the duct walls thicken and the duct fills with fluid. The milk duct can then become blocked or clogged with a thick, sticky substance. The condition often causes no symptoms, but some women may have nipple discharge, breast tenderness or inflammation of the clogged duct (periductal mastitis). Your chance of developing mammary duct ectasia — with or without inflammation — increases with age. Mammary duct ectasia usually improves without treatment. However, if symptoms persist despite self-care measures, you may need antibiotics or possibly surgery to remove the affected milk duct. Though it's normal to worry about any changes in your breasts, mammary duct ectasia and periductal mastisis aren't risk factors for breast cancer.

I am just looking for some input on an issue I have been having. I am trying make a doctor's appointment but he is closed today so I can't get through until tomorrow and I am driving myself crazy :S A little background is that I am 32 and a mother of 1. I do not have a history of breast cancer in my family but I did loose my mother to lung cancer about 7 years ago. So here it is.....about 3 months ago I developed an infection in my right nipple. Back in my younger, more crazy, years I had my nipples pierced. I took them out about 6 years ago but they never completely closed over. So because of my former piercings, I chalked my infection up to bacteria getting into the old holes. My doctor gave me antibiotics and it cleared up after about a week. Fast forward to today. I have noticed the look of my nipple steadily changing. When I had the infection there was a lump under my nipple which remains there today. The pain has long since disappeared but over the last few days it has gotten itchy and red all over my breast. My nipple, this is what concerns me the most, has not stuck out since the infection. It is almost flat and has a small indent right in the middle. I have always has flaky nipple skin which I just assumed was normal but now I am second guessing it. Stupid me started googling and of course the worse comes up and now I am concerned it might be Paget's disease. I am trying to convince myself that I am over reacting and that maybe everything just didn't heal right after the infection but I am stressing out. Has anyone else had similar issues with their nipple? Those who have been diagnosed with Paget's, what were your earliest symptoms?

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2013 04:13PM MelissaDallas wrote: What kind of benign was it? Truly benign things like fibroadenoma don't ever turn into cancer. Some kinds of atypia can continue to mutate & develop into cancer. It is also entirely possible to develop cancer in the same area of your breast totally unrelated to earlier findings. Typically, when you are put on six month followups for benign findings they are estimating that you have a less than 2% chance of having cancer.

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2014 07:51PM MelissaDallas wrote: Benisse, I would think you might get more frequent & earlier colonoscopy & extra gyn screening. Here's some info: The CHEK2 1100delC mutation identifies families with clustering of both colorectal and breast cancer, referred to as the hereditary breast and colorectal cancer phenotype(HBCC)[5]. The mutation, however, appears not to be the major contributor to the HBCC phenotype, thus limitimg its use in genetic counseling. Possibly, CHEK2 1100delC acts as a risk modifier in families with Lynch syndrome[18]. In a Swedish study, CHEK2 1100delC was not a major cause of double primary breast and colorectal cancer[6]. In Polish studies, positive associations with protein-truncating CHEK2 alleles were seen for cancers of the thyroid (OR 4.9), breast (OR 2.2), and prostate (OR 2.2). The missense variant I157T was associated with an increased risk of breast cancer (OR 1.4), colon cancer (OR 2.0), kidney cancer (OR 2.1), prostate cancer (OR 1.7), thyroid cancer (OR 1.9) and ovarian cystadenomas, borderline ovarian cancers and low-grade invasive ovarian cancers, but not no high grade ovarian cancer[12,15,17]. All mutation types combined were associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer (OR 1.9)[13]. In a Finnish population, the I157T mutation was observed more frequently in colorectal cancer patients than in controls. A trend towards higher frequency was seen in patients with multiple primary tumors and/or a family history of cancer[14]. A Danish-German study suggested a two-fold increase in melanoma risk for 1100delC carriers[23].

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2013 07:11PM MelissaDallas wrote: Ladyvulcan, first, you need to stop googling breast cancer:) Running track, big breasts & damp bras are prime breeding ground for friction irritations or fungal infections (yes, same thing as athletes foot or jock itch). You need to show your mom because you probably need either some over-the-counter antifungal ointment or powder or maybe just some cortisone cream. Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2013 03:28PM MelissaDallas wrote: you really need to get off Dr. Google, because he is not your friend, and docs have to go to school for a long time to be able to interpret what they see on the ultrasound, so stop trying to figure out what you think you saw. You don't say how old you are, but fibroadenomas are very common in young women, and if they see more than one mass, that is actually GOOD, because it makes it more likely that it is a fibro or something else benign. As to the shoulder and arm stuff, most women diagnosed with cancer had NO symptoms, besides maybe a lumpy or painful breast. Most likely the person giving you the ultrasound was the tech, not the doctor and they are not allowed to tell you anything. Hang in there! The odds are that this is nothing serious.

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2016 04:08AM MelissaDallas wrote: Generally they recommend an excisional biopsy when some kind of atypia are found, such as atypical ductal hyperplasia or atypical lobular hyperplasia or other conditions. In a low percentage of these lesions, about 20-25%, ductal carcinoma in situ or invasive cancer is found in the area of the atypical cells. In my case I had ADH on stereotactic biopsy, suspicious for LCIS. On the excisional biopsy LCIS (not considered cancer) was found, but nothing worse. In some ways I thought the surgical biopsy was easier than the stereotactic one

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2013 03:02PM MelissaDallas wrote: Linae, this is from a recent thread: "First, the "probably benign" wording that your radiologist used is actually the correct wording to define an image that has been rated as a BIRADs 3. As laypeople, the word "probably" doesn't give us the warm fuzzies but to a radiologist, it's means something quite different. A BIRADs 3 rating is only given to images that the radiologist judges to have less than a 2% chance of being cancer. Anything more than 2% and the radiologist will rate the image as a BIRADs 4 and recommend a biopsy. I recently read a study that indicated that in fact radiologists tend to be conservative about using the BIRADs 3 rating - they err on the side of caution and rate many images as BIRADs 4 when they could be BIRADs 3 - and the actual malignancy rate of BIRADs 3 images is 0.7%. BI-RADS 3 Probably Benign Finding - Initial Short-Interval Follow-Up Suggested: A finding placed in this category should have less than a 2% risk of malignancy. It is not expected to change over the follow-up interval, but the radiologist would prefer to establish its stability... www.radiologyassistant.nl/en/p... For something with such a low risk of being cancer, a 6 month follow-up is usually what's recommended because that is considered to be the most prudent approach. Radiologists try to avoid putting patients through unnecessary biospies. If the area of concern shows stability over 6 months, then the risk that it might be cancer drops well below the original 2%. If over the 6 months there is a change such as a reduction in the size of the mass, that would be good news indicating that the area of concern is not cancer. But if there is a change that indicates concern, then a biopsy will be done at that 6 month point. Breast cancer is usually very slow growing - it takes years for most cancers to grow to the point of even being visible on imaging - so the 6 month delay is extremely unlikely to impact a diagnosis. The other issue for radiologists is the simple fact that there is a lot of stuff that goes on in our breasts. 60% of women have fibrocystic breasts, which means that we have cysts or have other benign conditions that might show up on a mammogram or ultrasound. Radiologists are trained to distinguish between the appearance of these benign conditions and the appearance of cancer, but of course nothing can be 100% certain. That's the other reason for the word "probably". But if radiologists sent every woman with any fibrocystic condition in for an immediate biopsy, there would be thousands more biopsies done every day. And then when someone with a more serious concern needed to have a biopsy, the wait to get the biopsy would be longer." Another thing, when you start doing unnecessary biopsies you get scar tissue in your breasts that can obscure bad things you want seen.

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2017 06:14AM MelissaDallas wrote: Mary, I'm sorry you find yourself here. A. Get and keep copies of all your radiology reports and imaging so you know the descriptions and Bi-Rads ratings of anything being investigated. If you go to a different facility in the future you will be able to provide them for comparison. B. Absent a Bi-Rads 5 rating on your ultrasound, better than 80% of breast biopsies are benign. They recommend biopsy for anything they think could have even a 3% chance of being cancer. "Concerning" , "suspicious" and even "very suspicious" are commonly used and very subjective. Even "suspicious" edges often turn out to be nothing more than benign fibroadenomas that don't have a "classic" appearance. I told my mom, based on the "concerning" talk that I must have cancer. I didn't. You are not diagnosed until a biopsy says you are. Try not to read anything in to language and tone. The report would tell you a lot more

(This is the original recipe but I'll add my friend's shortcut at the end):  Fig Rye Bread from Bon Appetit, May '95 2 cups warm water 1 pk. dry yeast 1/2 tsp. sugar 1 Tbs. vegetable oil [I use olive] 1 Tbs. salt 3 2/3 cups (about) all purpose flour 2 cups whole grain rye flour 2-1/2 (12 oz.) cups dried black Mission figs or Calimyrna figs [I use both] Combine water, yeast and sugar in a large bowl. Stir to dissolve and let stand until foamy, about 8 minutes. Add oil and salt to yeast mixture. Gradually stir in 3-1/3 cups white flour and 2 cups rye flour. Knead dough on floured surface until smooth and elastic, adding more white flour if sticky, about 10 minutes. Place dough in larged oiled bowl. Cover with plastic wrap and a towel. Let rise in a warm place until doubled in volume, about 1 hour 15 minutes. Dust 2 large baking sheets with all purpose flour. Punch down dough. Turn out onto lightly floured surface. Press out to a 1" thick rectangle. Sprinkle on the figs and roll up jelly roll style. Knead to distribute figs evenly. Divide dough in half and roll each piece into a 16-inch long loaf. Transfer to prepared sheets. Cover with towel. Let rise in warm area until doubled, about 45 minutes. Preheat oven to 400*F. Bake loaves until golden and bottoms sound hollow when tapped, using spray bottle to spray oven with water every 10 minutes, about 45 minutes. Cool completely on racks. This bread freezes well. NOTE: Here is Julia Child's foolproof food processor bread dough method: Prepare yeast mixture in a measuring cup. Put all dry ingredients in processor [I use 3 cups white and 2 rye flour], using the plastic dough blade if you have it. Turn on machine and pour in the liquid, then the oil. Let run until dough forms a rapidly rotating ball, adding a little more water if dough doesn't come together (or a little more flour if too sticky to form a ball). Stop the machine and let dough rest 5 minutes. (Important!) Turn on the machine again and let dough ball rotate 30 times. Stop the machine, turn dough out outo a floured board and let rest 2 more minutes. Knead 50 strokes by hand. I also use Julia's trick of heating the oven with a cast iron skillet on the bottom, then throwing 1/2 cup water into the skillet to create the steam.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2013 05:05PM MelissaDallas wrote: The localization is not much different than a very long seated mammogram. You'll get one sting when they start the numbing & then just feel pressure. I think the idea of what they are doing is worse than the actual procedure. It's kind of awkward keeping your head & hair back & out of the way. The biopsy is surprisingly easy. You'll be a little sore & bruised. I think I only took one or two pain pills then took Aleve for a day or two. If you work you'll only need to be off a day or two unless you do significant lifting. I'm allergic to steristrips so they used surgical glue on my incision & I had to be a little more careful for a few days to not put any pull on it. There are a lot of us here who think excisional is easier than core needle. I was knocked out though.

Posts.Content: May 5, 2013 11:10AM MelissaDallas wrote: Hi Adrieann, Whoa there girl! Could it be malignant? Of course, you know it COULD be, but there are lots of benign things it could be too. Could be fibrocystic stuff or benign papilloma or phyllodes or othere things. 80% of masses on biopsy are benign. That is not to say that depending on what the biopsy shows that it may still need to come out. I think that if they were relatively certain it was definitely cancer they would have told you. As far as genetics, it would be a lot more concerning if your mom or sisters had breast cancer, especially if your granny didn't have it until she was older. Most breast cancer is not genetic. As far as waiting, it is the worst part of the whole process, but a few weeks doesn't make much difference in the grand scheme of things as far as if it is cancer because most are slow and have been growing for years before it shows up. Hang in there until you get your results, and don't get ahead of yourself, because this may not be so serious as you think. Hugs, Melissa

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 02:59AM MelissaDallas wrote: Domesticwoman, all multiple foci means is "in more than one place" or "different things in a breast". I saw you posted in the IDC forum asking why it is so difficult to get info on multifocal stuff. It is not. Probably more of us then not have multifocal stuff. Your fibrocystic stuff is multifocal be cause it is not just a single cyst or fibroid. My LCIS is multifocal because it is usually all over the place plus I also had a cyst. Many women with DCIS or other cancer have it in more than one spot, thus "multifocal" Chances are whatever they are checking on you will be more of the same benign stuff you already know about. Try not to get too anxious about it. Chances are it is fine.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 08:58PM MelissaDallas wrote: Gina, ALH is lower down the spectrum of risk than LCIS. Approximately 12% of all women develop breast cancer. It is estimated that 20% of women with LCIS will, so ALH falls somewhere in between. About an extra 4 or 5% absolute risk. You could request referral to a high risk breast clinic for risk assessment before you make any decision about Tamoxifen. There is certainly no hurry to decide anything. Also, unless lots of colon cancer runs in your family the endometrial cancer may not affect your risk.

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2013 06:14PM MelissaDallas wrote: HomeNews & EventsNewsroomPress Announcements - FDA NEWS RELEASE For Immediate Release: June 2, 2011 Media Inquiries: JeffreyVentura, 301-796-2807, jeffrey.ventura@fda.hhs.gov Consumer Inquiries: 888-INFO-FDA FDA: Breast thermography not a substitute for mammography Telethermographic, ‘infrared’ devices not approved for primary cancer screening The U.S. Food and Drug Administration today warned women not to substitute breast thermography for mammography to screen for breast cancer. Unlike mammography, in which an X-ray of the breast is taken, thermography produces an infrared image that shows the patterns of heat and blood flow on or near the surface of the body. Some health care providers claim thermography is superior to mammography as a screening method for breast cancer because it does not require radiation exposure or breast compression. However, the FDA is unaware of any valid scientific evidence showing that thermography, when used alone, is effective in screening for breast cancer. To date, the FDA has not approved a thermography device (also referred to as a telethermographic device) for use as a stand-alone to screen or diagnose breast cancer. The FDA has cleared thermography devices for use only as an additional diagnostic tool for breast cancer screening and diagnosis. Therefore, FDA says, thermography devices should not be used as a stand-alone method for breast cancer screening or diagnosis. “Mammography is still the most effective screening method for detecting breast cancer in its early, most treatable stages,” said Helen Barr, M.D., director of the Division of Mammography Quality and Radiation Programs in the FDA’s Center for Devices and Radiological Health. “Women should not rely solely on thermography for the screening or diagnosis of breast cancer.” The FDA has issued warning letters to some health care providers who have been promoting the inappropriate use of breast thermography. The letters instructed the providers to cease making claims that thermography devices, when used alone, are an effective means of detecting breast cancer. Claims have, for instance, appeared on some providers’ websites. The FDA encourages women to: • Have regular mammograms according to screening guidelines or as recommended by their health care provider; • Follow their health care provider’s recommendations for additional breast diagnostic procedures, such as various mammographic views, clinical breast exam, breast ultrasound, MRI or biopsy; additional procedures could include thermography; • Remember that thermography is not a substitute for mammography and should not be used by itself for breast cancer screening or diagnosis. “While there is plenty of evidence that mammography is effective in breast cancer detection, there is simply no evidence that thermography can take its place,” said Barr. For more information: Link to: Warning Letters Safety Communication Consumer Article #

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2014 06:29PM MelissaDallas wrote: A mammogram is a specialized X-ray of the breast. It can be used to evaluate a breast lump or other abnormality that has been detected by a breast self-exam (BSE) or a clinical breast examination. Mammography is also important as a screening tool because it can detect breast cancer at an early stage, before it can be felt on a physical exam. Mammogram interpretation is performed by a radiologist. When a radiologist interprets a mammogram, he or she assigns a score to it that indicates the radiologist's opinion as to the likelihood of cancer being present. The score is used to communicate with doctors about how concerned the radiologist is about the findings. The American College of Radiologists has developed national standards for rating mammograms. Your mammogram report may include a BIRADS (Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System) assessment. There are seven categories. If you achieve a score of 3, 4 or 5, you will require a follow-up study. Knowing your BIRADS score will help ensure that you get the proper follow-up after your mammogram. It is part of what you need to know to actively participate in your medical care. BIRADS 0 – Diagnosis: Incomplete, typically because more information is needed. Next steps: The mammogram or ultrasound didn't give the radiologist enough information to make a clear diagnosis; follow-up imaging is necessary. BIRADS 1 – Diagnosis: Negative (N). Next steps: There is nothing to comment on. Breasts are normal and routine screening is recommended. BIRADS 2 – Diagnosis: Benign Finding-Negative (N). Next steps: A definite negative mammogram; radiologist may describe benign finding, such as a lymph node within the breast, breast implants or a fibroadenoma (solid lump comprised of benign cells); routine screening recommended. BIRADS 3 – Diagnosis: Probably Benign Finding (P). Next steps: A finding is present that is most likely benign (>98%), but another evaluation should be made shortly. You'll be asked to follow-up with a repeat mammogram in six months. If you have a family or personal history of breast cancer, the radiologist may opt to do more tests now rather than wait. BIRADS 4 – Diagnosis: Suspicious Abnormality (S). Next steps: Lesions are present that don't have characteristics of breast cancer, but there is a reasonable probability of malignancy (20% to 35%); a biopsy should be considered. BIRADS 5 – Diagnosis: Highly Suspicious of Malignancy (M). Next steps: Lesion has a high probability of being cancer (>= 95%). Appropriate action should be taken. You will need to have a biopsy for diagnosis. Talk to your doctors about what course of action to take. BIRADS 6 – Diagnosis: Known Biopsy-Proven Malignancy. Next steps: Biopsy-detected malignancy is present but additional information is necessary.

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2013 06:35AM MelissaDallas wrote: Hi Canadian, To quell your anxiety somewhat, fibroids do not turn cancerous.  They are benign and stay benign.  They can, however get very large and uncomfortable, plus they can get so big that they can obscure other things going on in your breast when imaging is done so sometimes they are removed.  60% of women have fibrocystic breast conditions and usually you don't just have one fibroadenoma and may develop more in time.  Fibroadenomas and cysts may wax and wane with your menstrual period, or become painful at certain times of the month.  As far as your family history, they things that make for a strong family history are first degree relatives, so your great-aunt and mom's cousin probably don't indicate you are at high risk.  If your mom or sister had breast or ovarian cancer, especially at early ages, that would be a lot more concerning.

I had paternal grandmother & aunt with colon cancer and a dad who grows big polyps fast & you tested me for CHEK2 and PTEN before BRCA, all of which were negative. I have a network of high-risk friends through the breastcancer.org discussion boards who are on the six-month merry-go-round of monitoring for LCIS, ALH, ADH, etc. We saw this article http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2016/04/new-weapon-against-breast-cancer/?mc_cid=b0ef82a46d&mc_eid=00533c3e53 We are wondering if it is feasible or possible to have our stored biopsy samples KI-67 tested for additional information. Also, in the case of ALH/LCIS, since it is so frequently multifocal, would the individual areas of concern be like diagnosed cancer and potentially all have different KI-67 rates? The constant monitoring is so emotionally wearing and we would all be so excited to have additional information that might help more accurately evaluate our true risk. Individual risk assessment in our cases seems to be so lacking at this point in time. Some "high-riskers" are told anywhere from 25% to 80%, which isn't very helpful. Hope you are doing well. Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2017 06:39AM MelissaDallas wrote: My experience was that I really didn't need to worry about what to ask the counselor. She asked ME a LOT of questions and had me complete a very detailed questionaire/family tree. I don't remember them asking anything like ductal/lobular. Just which relatives had what kinds of cancers (prostate, etc.) & at what ages. Also about other things like thyroid disease. Also questions on nationalities/ethnicities. Not just female relatives-male also. Your Dad's side of the family too. She reviewed it with me and asked a bunch more questions. She then shared exactly which genetic syndromes she thought were a possibility I/my family might have and what specifically she was going to test me for. After the testing (negative) she also talked about future things. My Dad does NOT want to be tested, despite both his mom & sister having colon cancer. She suggested if we could talk him into it, polyps from his next colonoscopy could be sent to her for processing after pathology

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2013 03:58PM MelissaDallas wrote: They don't generally do the kind of follow up you were expecting after a mammotome biopsy. They usually don't examine you or take off the steri-strips. A mammotome biopsy is not going to remove all of a mass, especially a fibroadenoma which can be sizeable. Both of the biopsies were truly benign. Fibrocystic breasts tend to hurt, and at 38 you may be entering the early stages of perimenopause which can kick up hormonal problems and make it worse. While his office has not handled you well and he may not have the greatest bedside manner, I think part of your problem has been confusion on what you were expecting. Since you didn't like him you should see another doctor next time, but I think you should be fine to follow up with your next regularly scheduled mammogram. While cancer can hurt, realistically it is way down the list of likely causes. Despite all the hassle, you do have good, as in benign, results.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2014 09:43PM MelissaDallas wrote: That is a great report. Benign fibrocystic stuff only. Again, the point of the excisional biopsy was to confirm that there was no DCIS or invasive cancer in the area of the atypia.  The concept of clean margins is for confirmed cancer lumpectomy, not for an excisional biopsy. Posts.Content: May 25, 2013 02:19AM MelissaDallas wrote: Yes Kim, it is entirely normal. Usually a first biopsy is either ultrasound-guided or stereotactic, which is mammogram guided when the area is easily seen on ultrasound or mammo. If those come out benign then usually nothing further is done. If that biopsy showed cancer or atypical cells, the surgeon might or might not want an MRI before an excisional biopsy or lumpectomy. Please know that even though there is an area of concern 80% of biopsies turn out benign on Birads 4 rated mammograms. The odds are in your favor that this will turn out fine. The waiting is the worst part.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2017 07:08AM - edited Jan 31, 2017 07:08AM by MelissaDallas Post here. See what I meant about your other post being relative to this one? The whole subject is really you going through your testing to rule out cancer and what all happens to you. They are just being prudent, but I suppose they could have missed their target area because of the bleeding. About all that can be done about it now is to repeat the mammogram as they suggested in a month. I'm really sorry that happened to you. As far as "would it make a difference?". Probably not. Most cancers have been there for years before they are even big enough to be picked up by imaging, so a few weeks (or months) would make little, if any difference in the grand scheme of things. Lots of women who have already been diagnosed wait weeks and even a month or two while getting additional testing before surgery/treatment. I go through a very busy public hospital connected to an NCI Cancer Center. I had my screening mammogram the beginning of November, then didn't get my diagnostic mammogram until February, core biopsy in March and excisional biopsy in April-so going on six months through the process and they were not concerned about it at all.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2014 11:32AM MelissaDallas wrote: From Mayo Clinic: Answers from Sandhya Pruthi, M.D. "No. Fibrocystic breast changes don't increase your risk of breast cancer. Having fibrocystic breasts is very common. Women with this noncancerous (benign) condition often experience lumpy, painful breasts. The cause of fibrocystic breast changes isn't completely understood. But the condition is likely associated with hormone fluctuations during a woman's menstrual cycle. Although it doesn't increase your risk of breast cancer, having fibrocystic breasts may interfere with your ability to detect new breast lumps or other abnormal changes that might need to be evaluated by your doctor. It's important to become familiar with how your breasts normally feel so that you'll know when something just doesn't feel right." Again, fibroadenomas do NOT change into or become cancer. Also, cervical cancer is not a breast cancer risk because it is almost always caused by the HPV virus.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2018 10:47AM MelissaDallas wrote: No, the problem is that taking aspirin and ibuprofen together may be responsible for the whole situation. You had fibrocystic breast pain and took two anticoagulant drugs together that may have caused bleeding and bruising & hematoma that caused you to go to the doctor for a breast pain/hematoma. Nobody is seeing the whole situation because the doctor is telling you you have a bruise, but you don't believe him that you have a bruisebreast hematoma and haven't told him you took aspirin & ibuprofen together. Your next stop could be in the ER for dizzines or worse because you have internal bleeding from the drugs. It doesn't matter whether or not you remember "doing anything" to cause a bruise. The fact that you took aspirin & ibuprofen together may explain the whole thing.

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2017 05:49PM - edited Mar 22, 2017 05:49PM by MelissaDallas It is very common (about one in ten) to get called back for more views and/or an ultrasound for better clarity after a mammogram. It is even more common on first mammograms, as they have nothing to compare to to see if whatever "stuff" they see is stable. You already know from the "scattered fibroglandular tissue" that you have fibrocystic breasts. With more views on a diagnostic mammogram (and/or ultrasound) they may very well say, "yeah, definitely looks like a benign fibroadenoa-see you next year." Even if they aren't sure and have to biopsy whatever it is, better than 80% of those come back benign. Chances are you are just fine. Breast imaging just leaves a lot to be desired.

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2013 03:49AM MelissaDallas wrote: Rose, the estrogen in your body is not coming from your ovaries now. Here is how it works: Ovarian secretion of estrogen and progesterone ends. Once the ovaries have stopped producing estrogens, however, they still continue to produce small amounts of the male hormone testosterone, which can be converted to estrogen (estradiol) in body fat. In addition, the adrenal gland continues to produce androstenedione (a male hormone), which is converted to estrone and estradiol in the body fat. The total estrogen produced after menopause, however, is far less than that produced during a woman's reproductive years. The best thing you can do to lower your estrogen post-menopausally is to lose any excess weight & have as little body fat as possible.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2014 08:17PM MelissaDallas wrote: Ductal ectasia IS a benign finding & not a risk for cancer. If they aren't suggesting a biopsy I wouldn't worry about it. It is one of those "aging breasts" things. By Mayo Clinic Staff Mammary duct ectasia (ek-TAY-zhuh) occurs when a milk duct beneath your nipple becomes wider (dilated), the duct walls thicken and the duct fills with fluid. The milk duct can then become blocked or clogged with a thick, sticky substance. The condition often causes no symptoms, but some women may have nipple discharge, breast tenderness or inflammation of the clogged duct (periductal mastitis). Your chance of developing mammary duct ectasia — with or without inflammation — increases with age. Mammary duct ectasia usually improves without treatment. However, if symptoms persist despite self-care measures, you may need antibiotics or possibly surgery to remove the affected milk duct. Though it's normal to worry about any changes in your breasts, mammary duct ectasia and periductal mastisis aren't risk factors for breast cancer.

Posts.Content: May 5, 2013 04:27AM MelissaDallas wrote: Perhaps this will help. It is from an earlier post by one of our resident experts, Beesie: smillsbc, Seeding from a needle biopsy is possible, but it's extremely rare. Obviously seeding is not an issue if the biopsy result is benign, which happens in 80% of cases. It's also not an issue if cancer is diagnosed and the patient decides to have a mastectomy. For those who have a lumpectomy, usually radiation is given and the purpose of radiation is to kill off any rogue cancer cells that might be left in the breast - and that of course would include any that happened to be there as a result of seeding. Here's what the medical expert on this website says about seeding: What My Patients Are Asking: Can Getting a Biopsy Spread the Cancer? For those who are concerned about seeding, what I don't understand is why they don't have the same concerns with a surgical biopsy. Seeding can happen if any cancer cells end up on a surgical instrument and then that surgical instrument is moved somewhere else and those cancers cells drop off. With a surgical biopsy, the margins of the mass are not always clearly defined, so it's very possible that even when a surgeon thinks that he or she is cutting around a tumor, he/she may in fact be cutting through the edge of the tumor. Additionally, any of us who've read our pathology reports after surgery realize that usually the area of concern is removed in several pieces, not in a single mass. Surgeons are trained to be very careful with their surgical instruments, so seeding is very rare, but sometimes it does take happen. Personally I think seeding is as likely, if not more likely, to result from surgery than from a needle biopsy. But the most important point is that this is rare. And when it happens, the treatments that are given for the cancer itself should address and eliminate any concerns. When there is an option between a needle biopsy and a surgical biopsy, a needle biopsy is usually recommended because it is the safer option. Surgery comes with risks. Anaesthesia. Infections. Healing problems. And after surgery, you are left with scar tissue in your breast. This can make future mammogram and ultrasound screenings more difficult, plus it can lead to the development of calcifications or fatty necrosis. If calcs or fatty necrosis show up on your mammogram, there will be no way to know that it's benign and just the result of the surgery - and then another biopsy will be necessary. I'm pretty sure that at least one of my biopsies, if not two of them, are a direct result of having had an earlier excisional (surgical) biopsy on that breast. Everyone needs to do what they feel most comfortable doing. I'm not posting this to change anyone's mind. I probably shouldn't be posting this at all. But I'm concerned. There has been a lot of misinformation going around in the "Not Diagnosed" forum recently, unnecessarily driving up fear levels. The bigger problem is that I see women actually making decisions based on this misinformation, rather than on the advice of their doctors. So I feel it's important to offer up some different information. More from the experts on this website: Biopsy "Different techniques can be used to perform biopsy, and it’s likely that your surgeon will try to use the least invasive procedure possible — the one that involves the smallest incision and the least amount of scarring... ...Medical guidelines say that about 90% of biopsies should be needle biopsies, the least invasive procedure. Still, research has shown that about 70% of breast biopsies are surgical biopsies. This means that many women who don't have cancer are having unnecessary surgery. It also means that women who are diagnosed with breast cancer have to have a second operation to remove the cancer." . Mammogram Results: Breast Imaging Reporting and Database System (BI-RADS) Category Assessment Follow-up 3 Probably benign – means that there is Receive a 6 month a finding that is most likely benign, but follow-up should be followed in a shorter period mammogram. of time to see if the area of concern changes. 4 Suspicious abnormality – means that May require biopsy there are suspicious findings that could turn out to be cancer.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2013 11:51AM MelissaDallas wrote: Hi Brejim, I'm sorry you are going through this because I know it is frightening. You don't say whether your hyperplasia is ductal or lobular, but yes, sometimes your excisional biopsy will find "other" things. Not necessarily cancer though. My stereotactic biopsy showed atypical lobular hyperplasia, suspicious for lobular carcinoma in situ. The LCIS was confirmed on the excisional biopsy, but it is still not considered "cancer". It just ups my chances of eventually developing cancer, so I am just followed more closely than women with no findings on their mammograms. Sometimes they don't find anything else. I'm 51 and had never had an iffy mammogram either. Find out which type of hyperplasia you have. There are threads here on both ductal & lobular hyperplasia that may help answer some of your questions. Glad to have you here & to help. Melissa

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2013 03:52PM MelissaDallas wrote: Soriya, the process your doctors are following is absolutely a normal one when they can't tell what something is.  Needle biopsy, then excisional biopsy depending on what the finding is on needle biopsy.  The vast majority of biopsies are benign, more than 80% of them.  Fibroadenomas are hard lumps that aren't necessarily painful and are always benign.  The "warning" you got on dense breasts is standard language (legally required in the U.S.) to let you know that mammograms can't see everything in dense breasts.  Most women have dense breasts, especially young women.  Probably the only ones who don't are elderly, and some of them still have dense breasts.   You are scaring yourself unnecessarily, because there is every reason to believe right now that you DON'T have breast cancer. If it should turn out that you do, likely it is in an early stage and you will deal with it.

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2014 07:11AM MelissaDallas wrote: They only told me to limit my activity for a day, but if you have to have the excision you will have steristrips or surgical glue which may be uncomfortable & pull, especially with sweating. Bouncing would make it more likely to develop a hematoma or seroma. I don't know if a couple of months of bouncing could cause any migration of the biopsy marker that will be placed. I think it just depends on how the core comes back. It may very well be completely benign, in which case it is moot. If it just comes back with some atypia the doctor could well let you wait several months for the excision if you ask and are comfortable with the wait. I go to a really busy county clinic staffed by a local university medical center. There are long waits between appointments. It took me from the first of November to the end of April to get through mammo, diagnostic mammo, core biopsy then excisional biopsy, so when it does not appear to be an urgent case the wait could conceivably be as long as what yours would be if you waited.

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2014 09:37PM MelissaDallas wrote: Grammy, you are incorrect that it does nothing for us. a. There is often no visible mass for the surgeon to find so a marker is necessary. "Bad"tissue looks just like healthy tissue. The cancer can often only be seen under a microscope, so how else is the surgeon supposed to find it, or at least find it without lopping off half your breast? b. Biopsies create scarring which can be read as a mass on a mammogram, so that marker identifies areas that have previously been biopsied. They also identify the very specific area so it can be watched in the future. for more problems.

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2013 10:25PM - edited Aug 10, 2013 10:27PM by MelissaDallas Hi, I'm guessing atypical lobular or ductal hyperplasia were found? Yes, they may find nothing further on her excisional biopsy, but she would still be followed with more frequent screenings and possibly offered either Tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor to help lower her risk of developing cancer as these conditions are considered markers for being at higher risk of developing cancer. Once she has the excisional biopsy, if cancer is found she would still need further surgery - a lumpectomy or mastectomy depending on findings. Getting clear surgical margins for cancer are not the goal of a biopsy. I would prefer to be seen by a breast specialist, but some "general surgeons" ARE breast specialists. I have a friend who is such. She hasn't done anything except breast surgery in many years.

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2015 07:07PM MelissaDallas wrote: BI-RADS 2 is a benign category in the breast imaging reporting and data system. A finding placed in this category should have essentially a 100% chance of being benign. Examples of such lesions include Although BI-RADS 1 and BI-RADS 2 have an essentially 0% chance of malignancy, BI-RADS 1 is used in situations where the breast is completely unremarkable, and BI-RADS 2 is used when the radiologist wants to remark on a benign finding. Any BI-RADS 2 breast finding is not expected to change over the follow-up interval. The radiologist should mention that it is a definite benign lesion. Usual screening follow up is recommended.

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2013 10:17AM MelissaDallas wrote: Maintaining a healthy weight and exercise are the main things, regardless of what you eat to do that. Low carb & high fat? Low fat? Whatever it takes to get you there is more important than how you do it. High body fat ups your estrogen level, even if you are post menopausal. There is no magic diet. Low fat dairy has actually been shown to be beneficial and increase survival in those diagnosed. It is high fat dairy that seems to be problematic. The alcohol connection is really weak unless you habitually overindulge. If you like a glass of wine it probably doesn't hurt much, although I find it lowers my inhibition to where I tend to eat more. On the melatonin, it helps me sleep, but I found after taking it regularly that I started having extreme anxiety and hostile moods. On reading, that is not an uncommon reaction. Depending on your menopausal status, tamoxifen or an aromatase inhibitor greatly reduces your risk.

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2013 09:55PM MelissaDallas wrote: CEA normal range is o to 2.5 or up to 5.0 if you are a smoker. Above 20 can indicate metastatic cancer but can also be caused by inflamation. CA125 normal is less than 35. Conditions other than cancer that can cause high CA-125 values include: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Endometriosis. Uterine fibroids. Liver disease (such as hepatitis or cirrhosis). Pancreatitis. The first trimester of pregnancy. Certain times during the menstrual cycle. Lupus. Types of cancer that can cause high CA-125 values include: Ovarian cancer or cancer of the fallopian tubes or endometrium. Cancer of the pancreas, stomach, esophagus, liver, breast, colon, or lung. Cancers that have spread to the lining of the abdomen (peritoneum), including lymphoma. These types of cancers usually occur along with the buildup of fluid in the abdomen (ascites). What Affects the Test Results of a cancer antigen 125 test can be affected by: Medicines used to treat cancer. A recent radioactive scan, such as a bone scan. Abdominal surgery. The CA-125 test should be done at least 3 weeks after surgery. CA27-29 normal is less than 38. I can't speak for the breast cancer follow ups but my ovarian cancer quarterly labs are a general bloodwork panel and three tumor markers.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2018 01:09PM MelissaDallas wrote: Always remember that Tamoxifen and AIs are not the same class of drugs and do not have equivalent side effects, especially in premenopausal vs. menopausal women. I see lots of posts here where women are attributing purported potential side effects of aromatase inhibitors with tamoxifen and the drugs are completely different and are not equivalent. Tamoxifen leaves circulating estrogen intact and prevents that estrogen from binding to estrogen receptors in your breasts. Aromatase inhibitors prevent postmenopausal (or women who undergo ovarian suppression) from converting androgens to estrogen. That is a very simplified explanation, but the drugs do indeed work completely differently and have different side effects.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 08:12PM - edited May 7, 2012 08:13PM by MelissaDallas I got that same thing recently with an anesthesiologist resident who did my pre-op.  I had told my breast surgeon that in the four procedures I've had in the past year that conscious sedation doesn't work well on me.  I can quote back the conversations that took place in the procedure room and I watched my own colonoscopy on the screen and experienced pain when everyone else I talk to doesn't remember anything at all.  I am becoming seriously creeped out - and it is not the pain I am complaining about.  My breast surgeon told me to bring it up to him.  He basically just said that some docs just like their patients more aware than others.  Four different docs in two different hospitals???  I have read that some people are rapid metabolizers of Versed and that is most likely the problem. I feel like I got the same crap for 13 years when I started experiencing hormonal problems at around 37 and all the doctors would just give me that "well, at your age" speech.  I also feel like they blew me off because I was heavy.  We now know that this was probably when my ovarian tumor started developing.  It took putting on a massive amount of ascites, a pulmonary embolism, sky-high tumor markers, cardiac arryhtmia & almost dying for them to finally discover my 20 POUND ovarian tumor.  Even the first three days in the hospital I was getting the "has anyone ever told you you have cirrhosis?" speech.  I kept telling them that didn't make sense because I had no risk factors plus had normal labs and an essentially normal abdominal CT.  You wouldn't have thought I even had a body below my waist.  Only after undergoing an unnecessary liver biopsy did they finally do a pelvic CT on me.  Surprise, surprise.

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2013 08:36PM MelissaDallas wrote: the 20% is for a birads 4. You have a Birads 3 which has an estimated risk of less than THREE PERCENT chance, NOT 20. With a Birads 3 no biopsy is recommended. A six month follow up is recommended. Heterogeneously dense breasts are what most of us have. It is extreme density that is concerning and you don't have that. Most of us develop calcifications as we age and only when they form certain patterns are they very concerning and yours are not. It is a shame you couldn't afford the BRCA testing.

Posts.Title: Weird Indentation Juliana1835 Juliana1835

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2013 10:36AM MelissaDallas wrote: Pretty good that you don't.  About 80% of biopsies are benign. Try not to go there until you get there.  We see women here all the time convinced that they have cancer (sometimes all appearances to the contrary) and they literally make themselves sick over something that turns out to be nothing.  I know the waiting is really hard, but try to find something else to keep your mind occupied.  If it does turn out to be cancer you will have time to deal with it then. Also, your family history is not as troubling as you think.  Your grandmother being diagnosed at 60 is not nearly as "risky" as if your mother was diagnosed at 30.  Your first cousin is pretty far down the list too to the genetics counselor.  They really look hard at first degree relatives.  Your cousin's could have come from the other side of her family too.

Posts.Content: Dec 25, 2012 07:03AM MelissaDallas wrote: If SIL is the owner of the policy the insured CANNOT cancel the policy or change the beneficiary. Only the policy owner can do that. It would be a lot more complicated than what you are stating depending on how the policy is set up. I worked in insurance for many years. If the insured is the policy owner & SIL is just paying the premiums that would be different. Perhaps the SIL helped her with this so that her final expenses would be taken care of & that the policy would be paid & not lapse if she should become too ill to maintain it. If the policy was taken out after she became ill it would have to be a guaranteed issue policy which would be for a fairly minimal amount of coverage.

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2013 07:14PM MelissaDallas wrote: I don't know how close you are to Atlanta, but I would try for a National Cancer Institute designated facility. They are the cream of the crop. The Winship Cancer Institute at Emory University is the only one listed in Georgia. Also, can I make one suggestion? It sounds like your Mom is still mentally sharp. You want to do everything you can for her and it helps you to feel like you are doing something. Don't treat her like a child and try to make all the decisions for her. I am only 52, but when I had ovarian cancer the hardest part for me was I felt like I was having my autonomy taken away. I was sick, not incompetent. My mother, bless her heart, just about drove me insane and was really making me angry trying to do everything for me. She was a huge help, but I told my sister I was surprised she wasn't following me into the bathroom & jerking the TP out of my hand:) One day in the hospital they brought my meal tray and she kept doing things like grabbing things off my tray to open them for me when I was perfectly capable of doing it myself. I just wanted to start screaming and never stop. I finally had to tell her that I would ask her if I needed help. The hardest part of being sick is feeling like your whole self has been taken over by other people.

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2016 07:51PM MelissaDallas wrote: Here's one thing I found on Pubmed: The aetiology of focal, preganancy-like mammary changes in non-pregnant and non-lactating women is discussed on the basis of the literature and a material of 31 patients. Such changes were found in one or more glandular lobules in 3 per cent of the breast tissue specimens received in our departments. As a rule, this finding was made in women who had been pregnant and who had been or were on oestrogenic or on contraceptive medication. They occurred in fertile, menopausal, as well as in post-menopausal women. Often they were seen many years after the pregnancy and/or intake of hormones. They were observed also in women who had never been pregnant or on hormone medication, and even in men on oestrogen therapy. It is likely, therefore, that focal pregnancy-like changes in non-pregnant and non-lactating women indicate a selective susceptibility of the mammary glandular tissue to oestrogen. Accordingly, we interpret the change as a normal histological variant.

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2013 08:18PM MelissaDallas wrote: If they wanted you to come back in 6 months they are 98% certain it is benign and not cancer and a biopsy is NOT recommended. When you have unnecessary biopsies you create scarring in your breast that can cause problems in reading future mammograms and actually lead to more biopsies. Here is how Birads works. With a six month f/u you were rated a 3 or 2. The American College of Radiology (ACR) has developed a standard way of describing mammogram findings. In this system, the results are sorted into categories numbered 0 through 6. This system is called the Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS). Having a standard way of reporting mammogram results lets doctors use the same words and terms and ensures better follow up of suspicious findings. Here’s a brief review of what the categories mean: This means a possible abnormality may not be clearly seen or defined and more tests are needed, such as the use of spot compression (applying compression to a smaller area when doing the mammogram), magnified views, special mammogram views, or ultrasound. This also suggests that the mammogram should be compared with older ones to see if there have been changes in the area over time. There’s no significant abnormality to report. The breasts look the same (they are symmetrical) with no masses (lumps), distorted structures, or suspicious calcifications. In this case, negative means nothing bad was found. This is also a negative mammogram result (there’s no sign of cancer), but the reporting doctor chooses to describe a finding known to be benign, such as benign calcifications, lymph nodes in the breast, or calcified fibroadenomas. This ensures that others who look at the mammogram will not misinterpret the benign finding as suspicious. This finding is recorded in the mammogram report to help when comparing to future mammograms. The findings in this category have a very good chance (greater than 98%) of being benign (not cancer). The findings are not expected to change over time. But since it’s not proven benign, it’s helpful to see if an area of concern does change over time. Follow-up with repeat imaging is usually done in 6 months and regularly thereafter until the finding is known to be stable (usually at least 2 years). This approach helps avoid unnecessary biopsies, but if the area does change over time, it allows for early diagnosis. Findings do not definitely look like cancer but could be cancer. The radiologist is concerned enough to recommend a biopsy. The findings in this category can have a wide range of suspicion levels. For this reason, some doctors may divide this category further: Not all doctors use these subcategories. The findings look like cancer and have a high chance (at least 95%) of being cancer. Biopsy is very strongly recommended. This category is only used for findings on a mammogram that have already been shown to be cancer by a previous biopsy. Mammograms may be used in this way to see how well the cancer is responding to treatment. Mammogram reports can also include an assessment of breast density. BI-RADS classifies breast density into 4 groups: This means that fibrous and glandular tissue makes up less than 25% of the breast Fibrous and glandular tissue makes up from 25 to 50% of the breast. The breast has more areas of fibrous and glandular tissue (from 51 to 75%) that are found throughout the breast. This can make it hard to see small masses (cysts or tumors). The breast is made up of more than 75% fibrous and glandular tissue. This can lead to missing some cancers. In some states, the summary of the mammogram report that is sent to patients (sometimes called the lay summary) must contain information about breast density. This information may be worded in lay language instead of the BIRADS categories. Women whose mammograms show BI-RADS 3 or 4 for breast density may be told that they have “dense breasts.”

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 04:41PM MelissaDallas wrote: Sclerosing adenosis is composed of small breast lumps caused by an enlarged lobule  It may appear as a breast lump or an abnormal finding on a mammogram and may be painful. Because sclerosing adenosis has a distorted shape, it may be mistaken for breast cancer on a mammogram and a biopsy may be needed to confirm the diagnosis . However, it is a benign condition and does not need treatment    Sclerosing adenosis may be found with atypical hyperplasia, lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) . Although some studies have shown sclerosing adenosis slightly increases the risk of breast cancer, recent findings suggest it does not increase risk.   Sommer, I don't think it is the same as radial scars.

Posts.Title: Breast cancer and antidepressants vandoulini ChiSandy

Posts.Content: Jul 6, 2013 06:23PM MelissaDallas wrote: At eighteen it is more than likely a cyst. Benign fibrocystic condition is very common in late teens and young women. You may notice that they become painful around your period and that it gets better afterward. You really should get it checked because your doctor can give you some tips like avoiding caffeine, etc. that can possibly minimize your symptoms if that is what it is. If you take birth control pills that may aggravate it too. Part of being a grown up is learning to take care of yourself and getting regular check-ups. I'll bet, even if it takes a few tries you can find a gynecologist, possibly a woman, that you can learn to trust and like. Worrying about stuff and not getting it checked to reassure yourself is scarier than a good doctor.

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2013 10:09AM MelissaDallas wrote: You need to have the MRI and excisional biopsy.  They want to make sure nothing else is lurking.  My initial biospy was ALH, suspicious for LCIS.  The excisional biopsy did indeed confirm the LCIS.  They want the MRI because lobular stuff is sneaky and difficult to spot on mammos or ultrasounds.
Posts.Title: Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia-minute focus what's the relevance Scaredandworried concernmom

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2013 06:17AM MelissaDallas wrote: He recommended that knowing you had the vein surgery? I had a pulmonary embolism when I was very ill from ovarian cancer and the oncologist will not let me take Evista because of the clotting risk.  They have offered me Aromasin which does not have the clotting risk, but I am still thinking about it.  Not sure if it is available to premenopausal patients. For now I believe I am going to just stick to close monitoring and not worry about it so much.  In reality, most women with my condition don't get breast cancer.  You can have a talk with your doctor and ask what your ABSOLUTE risk difference is.  If it is just a few percentage points, then it would seem reasonable that the risk from clotting is too high for the few points in breast cancer risk reduction that tamoxifen would provide.

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2013 10:52PM MelissaDallas wrote: NO, most calcifications do NOT mean cancer. Certain patterns can be suspicious but most are not and a Birads 2 is a clearly benign result. Mammograms and ultrasounds "see" different things. What the ultrasound could see as a palpable lump can be just an area of denser breast tissue. This is a very good report and there is nothing at all seen for you to be worried about.
